Dublin, Ireland                                   Share       Delicious     Digg This     Reddit        Stumble Upon     Technorati     Twitter        Facebook     Windows Live     Yahoo                 MySpace     Email                   Bread Crumbs                Home          >           Academics          >           Undergraduate          >           Global Study          >           Gallatin Travel Courses          >            Dublin: James Joyce and Interdisciplinary Modernism                            Dublin: James Joyce and Interdisciplinary Modernism        IDSEM-UG 1743; Professor Greg Erickson  Spring 2014   NOTE: This spring semester Gallatin course is based in Washington Square, and the class will travel as a group to Dublin, Ireland over Spring Recess as part of the course.                             James Joyce         Eligibility   This course is open to currently enrolled undergraduate students of all NYU schools. Students must be in good academic and disciplinary standing to participate.          Course Description          In this course students will read and discuss the major works of James Joyce with a focus on their significance to Modernism, literary theory, and to interdisciplinary scholarship. Students will examine such texts as Dubliners , A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man , Ulysses , and sections of Finnegans Wake , paying particular attention to how different movements in literary theory have responded to Joyce's work. The exploration of interdisciplinarity will include discussions of Joyce's relationship with music, religion, post-colonialism, history, sexuality, philosophy, intellectual property and Irish Studies. The class will also look at representations of Joyce's work in music, dance, visual art, theater and film. The course will include guest speakers and several events at NYU's Glucksman Ireland House.   Over Spring Break, the class will travel to Dublin, Ireland to explore sites of relevance to Joyce's works and life. Students will travel on a group flight purchased by Gallatin which departs from NYC on March 16, and returns to NYC on March 23, 2014. Please note that travel is required to participate in the class, and students must reside in accommodations provided by Gallatin.          Tuition and Fees          Tuition for 4 credits: regular spring tuition applies; please see the NYU Bursar's Website for more information     Program fee: $800 (includes roundtrip flight, accommodations, excursions and some meals)          Application Requirements           APPLICATION HAS CLOSED; we are no longer accepting applications.     Your application will be reviewed only after the following items have been received by Gallatin's Office of Global Programs:     Completed application form   Personal Statement     Unofficial Transcript   Brief letter of recommendation from a faculty member or primary academic adviser     Admission decisions are based on strength of academic performance, personal statement, and space remaining in the program. Program is filled on a rolling basis and may fill without notice. Applicants will be notified of their application satus on or before Nov. 11, 2013. After students have been notified of his or her acceptance, an initial non-refundable deposit of $400 will be required to secure his or her place in the program.                    top of page                 Faculty Profile                             Professor Greg Erickson         Greg Erickson has taught at the Gallatin School since 2004, specializing in courses on modern literature, popular culture, religion, and music. Professor Erickson is trained as a literary scholar and as a classical musician and performs regularly with professional orchestras and chamber ensembles. more>                             Dublin, Ireland           Course application     deadline:   OCTOBER 25, 2013                                 Dublin, Ireland                                                               NYU Gallatin Footer              Gallatin School of Individualized Study     1 Washington Place     New York, NY 10003     (212) 998-7370                   A–Z Index      Directions      Contact Us      Job Opportunities               News      Support Gallatin      Feedback                         Follow us on Facebook      Follow us on Twitter      Follow us on Youtube         Follow us Instagram                 Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright NYU Gallatin. Prof. Luke Gibbons on 'Joyce’s Ghosts'    | Glucksman Ireland House | New York University                                              Skip to page Content.     NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                       Home       About Us       Undergraduate Studies       Graduate Studies       Academic Initiatives       Events       Membership       Community             Stay Connected           sign up       like us on Facebook       follow us on Twitter       watch us on Youtube       now on iTunes       listen to our radio hour                 Home > Events > Prof. Luke Gibbons on 'Joyce’s Ghosts'             Prof. Luke Gibbons on 'Joyce’s Ghosts'   Thursday, April 2nd, 7:00 p.m.         at       Glucksman Ireland House NYU     In his lecture, “Joyce’s Ghosts,” Luke Gibbons proposes that Joyce’s Irishness is intrinsic to his modernism, and is not just a source of subject matter but of form itself. Joyce’s stylistic innovations are haunted by memory that slips its moorings in inner life, and circulates through the silences and shadows of a colonial counter-public sphere. Luke Gibbons is professor of Irish literary and cultural studies at Maynooth University, Ireland, and the author of several books. He is Visiting Professor at NYU for Spring 2015.      Introduction by Professor John P. Waters , Clinical Assistant Professor of Irish Studies, NYU.          Free admission to Members of Glucksman Ireland House and to all students/faculty with a valid NYU I.D. card. For non-members: $10 donation at the door for the general event series.    In order to ensure a seat at events, please RSVP by submitting the form below, or by calling 212-998-3950 (option 3) or by emailing ireland.house@nyu.edu , except for the Blarney Star Concert Series which does not accept reservations.      All events are supported by members of Glucksman Ireland House. Become a member .                                      Áras Glucksman na hÉireann                      Ollscoil Nua Eabhrac                  Glucksman Ireland House                  New York University                  One Washington Mews                  New York, NY 10003                  U.S.A.             Directions     Phone: 212.998.3950   Fax: 212.995.4373         Email:        ireland.house@nyu.edu         Sitemap | Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Abby Bender    | Glucksman Ireland House | New York University                                              Skip to page Content.     NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                       Home       About Us       Undergraduate Studies       Graduate Studies       Academic Initiatives       Events       Membership       Community             Stay Connected           sign up       like us on Facebook       follow us on Twitter       watch us on Youtube       now on iTunes       listen to our radio hour                 Home > People > Abby Bender             Abby Bender     Adjunct Assistant Professor of Irish Studies   Ph.D. Princeton University; M.A. Princeton University; B.A. Vassar College       Office Address:   1 Washington Mews  New York, NY 10003   Office Hours:   Mondays and Wednesdays 10:30 - 11:15am   Email:        Phone:   212-998-3950   Fax:   212-995-4373       Areas of Research/Interest:   19th and 20th Century British and Irish Literature; James Joyce; Modernism and Empire; The Irish Literary Revival       Bio   Abby Bender received her Ph.D. in English from Princeton University in 2006. Her research and teaching interests focus on Irish literature and culture in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, with an approach often informed by religious and political history, as well as transnational, postcolonial, and cultural studies. Her book Israelites in Erin: Exodus, Revolution, and the Irish Revival , is published by Syracuse University Press (Fall 2015).      Professor Bender’s other publications include essays on Irish-Mexican solidarity during the Mexican-American War (in Genre: Forms of Discourse and Culture ), Roger Casement’s influence on James Joyce (in the James Joyce Quarterly ), the politics of Lady Gregory’s biblical allusions (in The Princeton Library Chronicle ), and Joyce’s use of Jewish collective memory, and specifically the Passover Haggadah, as a model for Irish national memory in Ulysses (in Memory Ireland Volume 4: Joyce and Cultural Memory ). Professor Bender’s new book project is tentatively titled Nursing the Nation: Breastfeeding in Modern Irish Writing .       Professor Bender has been an invited speaker at The Columbia University Irish Studies Seminar, The James Joyce Summer School in Dublin, The New York Public Library, and the inaugural Memorial Lecture for Professor Barbara Gluck at the Baruch College Jewish Studies Center, CUNY. At NYU, she teaches courses on Irish Drama, James Joyce, Contemporary Irish Fiction, and Women’s Writing in Ireland.      ***      "As in my research, an interest in moments of cultural contact—whether actual or imaginative—motivates my teaching. I arrived in Irish Studies via Modernism, the Bible, and Jewish Studies, and I continue to focus on expressions of transcultural and transnational sympathy and connection. I love how the students and faculty at Glucksman Ireland House are similarly expanding the scope of Irish Studies as a field, through work that is interdisciplinary, cross-cultural, and dynamic.      "I have prized the opportunity to mentor both undergraduates and graduate students on exciting research projects, and many of these projects have found audiences beyond our coursework, at conferences and as expanded M.A. theses, for example. Working individually with students to help them develop their original ideas is perhaps the most rewarding aspect of my job, and at GIH it’s a mode that’s fostered by the intimacy and intensity of seminar-style classes that typically meet in the wonderful space of the house itself."   Selected Works:   Israelites in Erin: Exodus, Revolution, and the Irish Revival (Syracuse: Syracuse University Press, 2015). “The Bloomsday Seder: Joyce and Jewish Memory,” in Memory Ireland Volume 4: Joyce and Cultural Memory , eds. Oona Frawley and Katherine O'Callaghan (Syracuse: Syracuse University Press, 2014).    “The Language of the Outlaw: A Clarification,” a note relating to Roger Casement and Ulysses , James Joyce Quarterly , 44:4 (Summer 2007).    “Lady Gregory’s Bible Lessons: The Deliverer and The Story Brought by Brigit ,” Princeton University Library Chronicle (Special Irish Theater Issue) 68:1-2 (Fall 2006-Winter 2007).    Review of Irish Orientalism: A Literary and Intellectual History by Joseph Lennon, The James Joyce Literary Supplement , 19:1 (Spring 2005).    “Irish-Mexican Solidarity and the San Patricio Battalion Flag,” Genre: Forms of Discourse and Culture 36:3 (Fall/Winter 2003).
